paragraphs.text:
%md

# Intro to Spark with Python
#### RDDs, DataFrames, and Spark Streaming
by Robert Hryniewicz
ver 0.8

result.msg:
Intro to Spark with Python

RDDs, DataFrames, and Spark Streaming

by Robert Hryniewicz
ver 0.8

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Introduction

This lab consists of three parts. In each section you will perform a basic Word Count.
#
In Part 1, we will introduce RDDs, Spark's primary low-level abstraction, and several core concepts.
#
In Part 2, we will introduce DataFrames, a higher-level abstraction than RDDs, along with SparkSQL allowing you to use SQL statements to query a temporary table.
#
In Part 3, we will introduce Spark Streaming, allowing you to compute near-realtime data using micro-batches. This is useful for data in motion. In this part you will use *Shell in a Browser* to run a Spark Streaming job.

result.msg:
Introduction

This lab consists of three parts. In each section you will perform a basic Word Count.

In Part 1, we will introduce RDDs, Spark's primary low-level abstraction, and several core concepts.

In Part 2, we will introduce DataFrames, a higher-level abstraction than RDDs, along with SparkSQL allowing you to use SQL statements to query a temporary table.

In Part 3, we will introduce Spark Streaming, allowing you to compute near-realtime data using micro-batches. This is useful for data in motion. In this part you will use Shell in a Browser to run a Spark Streaming job.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Concepts

At the core of Spark is the notion of a Resilient Distributed Dataset (RDD), which is an immutable and fault-tolerant collection of objects that is partitioned and distributed across multiple physical nodes of a YARN cluster that can be operated in parallel.
#
Typically, RDDs are instantiated by loading data from a shared filesystem, HDFS, HBase, or any data source offering a Hadoop InputFormat on a YARN cluster.
#
Once an RDD is instantiated, you can apply a [series of operations](https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/programming-guide.html#rdd-operations). All operations fall into one of two types: **[Transformations](https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/programming-guide.html#transformations)** or **[Actions](https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/programming-guide.html#actions)**. Transformation operations, as the name suggests, create new datasets from an existing RDD and build out the processing Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) that can then be applied on the partitioned dataset across the YARN cluster. An Action operation, on the other hand, executes DAG and returns a value.
#
In this lab we will use the following **Transformations**:
- map(func)
- filter(func)
- flatMap(func)
- reduceByKey(func)

and **Actions**:

- collect()
- count()
- take()
- takeOrdered(n, [ordering])
- countByKey()

A typical Spark application has the following four phases:

```
┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓
┃                       ┃
┃      Instantiate      ┃
┃      Input RDDs       ┃
┃                       ┃
┗━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━┛
            │
            │
┏━━━━━━━━━━━▼━━━━━━━━━━━┓
┃                       ┃
┃    Transform RDDs     ┃
┃                       ┃
┃                       ┃
┗━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━┛
            │
            │
┏━━━━━━━━━━━▼━━━━━━━━━━━┓
┃                       ┃
┃        Persist        ┃
┃   Intermediate RDDs   ┃
┃                       ┃
┗━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━┛
            │
            │
┏━━━━━━━━━━━▼━━━━━━━━━━━┓
┃                       ┃
┃    Action on RDDs     ┃
┃                       ┃
┃                       ┃
┗━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┛
```

result.msg:
Concepts

At the core of Spark is the notion of a Resilient Distributed Dataset (RDD), which is an immutable and fault-tolerant collection of objects that is partitioned and distributed across multiple physical nodes of a YARN cluster that can be operated in parallel.

Typically, RDDs are instantiated by loading data from a shared filesystem, HDFS, HBase, or any data source offering a Hadoop InputFormat on a YARN cluster.

Once an RDD is instantiated, you can apply a series of operations. All operations fall into one of two types: Transformations or Actions. Transformation operations, as the name suggests, create new datasets from an existing RDD and build out the processing Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) that can then be applied on the partitioned dataset across the YARN cluster. An Action operation, on the other hand, executes DAG and returns a value.

In this lab we will use the following Transformations:

  • map(func)
  • filter(func)
  • flatMap(func)
  • reduceByKey(func)

and Actions:

  • collect()
  • count()
  • take()
  • takeOrdered(n, [ordering])
  • countByKey()

A typical Spark application has the following four phases:

┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓
┃                       ┃
┃      Instantiate      ┃
┃      Input RDDs       ┃
┃                       ┃
┗━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━┛
            │
            │
┏━━━━━━━━━━━▼━━━━━━━━━━━┓
┃                       ┃
┃    Transform RDDs     ┃
┃                       ┃
┃                       ┃
┗━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━┛
            │
            │
┏━━━━━━━━━━━▼━━━━━━━━━━━┓
┃                       ┃
┃        Persist        ┃
┃   Intermediate RDDs   ┃
┃                       ┃
┗━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━┛
            │
            │
┏━━━━━━━━━━━▼━━━━━━━━━━━┓
┃                       ┃
┃    Action on RDDs     ┃
┃                       ┃
┃                       ┃
┗━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┛

paragraphs.text:
%md 

## Part 1
#### Introduction to RDDs with Word Count example

result.msg:
Part 1

Introduction to RDDs with Word Count example

paragraphs.text:
%md
In this section you will perform a basic word count with RDDs.
#
You will download external text data file to your sandbox. Then you will perform lexical analysis, or tokenization, by breaking up text into words/tokens.
The list of tokens then becomes an input for further processing to this and following sections.
#
By the end of this section you should have learned how to perform low-level transformations and actions with Spark RDDs and lambda expressions.

result.msg:
In this section you will perform a basic word count with RDDs.

You will download external text data file to your sandbox. Then you will perform lexical analysis, or tokenization, by breaking up text into words/tokens.
The list of tokens then becomes an input for further processing to this and following sections.

By the end of this section you should have learned how to perform low-level transformations and actions with Spark RDDs and lambda expressions.

paragraphs.text:
%md
In the next paragraph we are going to download data using shell commands. 
A shell command in a Zeppelin notebook can be invoked by prepending a block of shell commands with a line containing `%sh` characters.

result.msg:
In the next paragraph we are going to download data using shell commands.
A shell command in a Zeppelin notebook can be invoked by prepending a block of shell commands with a line containing %sh characters.

paragraphs.title: Prepare Directories and Download a Dataset
paragraphs.text:
%sh
cd /tmp

#  Remove old dataset file if already exists in local /tmp directory
if [ -e /tmp/About-Apache-NiFi.txt ]
then
    rm -f /tmp/About-Apache-NiFi.txt
fi

# Remove old dataset if already exists in hadoop /tmp directory
if hadoop fs -stat /tmp/About-Apache-NiFi.txt
then
   hadoop fs -rm  /tmp/About-Apache-NiFi.txt
fi

# Download "About-Apache-NiFi" text file
wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/roberthryniewicz/datasets/master/About-Apache-NiFi.txt

# Move dataset to hadoop /tmp
hadoop fs -put About-Apache-NiFi.txt /tmp

hadoop fs -cat /tmp/About-Apache-NiFi.txt | head

result.msg:
Apache NiFi Overview 
Team dev@nifi.apache.org 

What is Apache NiFi? Put simply NiFi was built to automate the flow of data between systems. While the term dataflow is used in a variety of contexts, we’ll use it here to mean the automated and managed flow of information between systems. This problem space has been around ever since enterprises had more than one system, where some of the systems created data and some of the systems consumed data. The problems and solution patterns that emerged have been discussed and articulated extensively. A comprehensive and readily consumed form is found in the Enterprise Integration Patterns [eip]. 

Some of the high-level challenges of dataflow include: 

Systems fail 
Networks fail, disks fail, software crashes, people make mistakes.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Next we are going to run Spark Python (or PySpark) that can be invoked by prepending a block of Python code with a line containing `%pyspark`.

result.msg: Next we are going to run Spark Python (or PySpark) that can be invoked by prepending a block of Python code with a line containing %pyspark.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#
The important thing to notice in the next paragraph is the `sc` object or Spark Context. Spark Context is automatically created by your driver program in Zeppelin.
#
Spark Context is the main entry point for Spark functionality. A Spark Context represents the connection to a Spark cluster, and can be used to create RDDs, which we will do next.
#
Remember that Spark doesn't have any storage layer, rather it has connectors to HDFS, S3, Cassandra, HBase, Hive etc. to bring data into memory. Thus, in the next paragraph you will read data (that you've just downloaded) from HDFS.

result.msg:
The important thing to notice in the next paragraph is the sc object or Spark Context. Spark Context is automatically created by your driver program in Zeppelin.

Spark Context is the main entry point for Spark functionality. A Spark Context represents the connection to a Spark cluster, and can be used to create RDDs, which we will do next.

Remember that Spark doesn't have any storage layer, rather it has connectors to HDFS, S3, Cassandra, HBase, Hive etc. to bring data into memory. Thus, in the next paragraph you will read data (that you've just downloaded) from HDFS.

paragraphs.title: Read Text File from HDFS and Preview its Contents
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Parallelize text file using pre-initialized Spark context (sc)
lines = sc.textFile("/tmp/About-Apache-NiFi.txt")

# Take a look at a few lines with a take() action.
print lines.take(4)

# Output: Notice that each line has been placed in a seperate array bucket.

result.msg: [u'Apache NiFi Overview ', u'Team dev@nifi.apache.org ', u'', u'What is Apache NiFi? Put simply NiFi was built to automate the flow of data between systems. While the term dataflow is used in a variety of contexts, we\u2019ll use it here to mean the automated and managed flow of information between systems. This problem space has been around ever since enterprises had more than one system, where some of the systems created data and some of the systems consumed data. The problems and solution patterns that emerged have been discussed and articulated extensively. A comprehensive and readily consumed form is found in the Enterprise Integration Patterns [eip]. ']

paragraphs.text:
%md
#
In the next paragraphs we will start using Python lambda (or anonymous) functions. If you're unfamiliar with lambda expressions, review [python docs] (https://docs.python.org/2/tutorial/controlflow.html#lambda-expressions) before proceeding.

result.msg: In the next paragraphs we will start using Python lambda (or anonymous) functions. If you're unfamiliar with lambda expressions, review python docs before proceeding.

paragraphs.title: Extract All Words from the Document
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
# Here we're tokenizing our text file by using the split() function. Each original line of text is split into words or tokens on a single space.
#  Also, since each line of the original text occupies a seperate bucket in the array, we need to use
#  a flatMap() transformation to flatten all buckets into a asingle/flat array of tokens.

words = lines.flatMap(lambda line: line.split(" "))

%md
Note that after you click 'play' in the paragraph above "nothing" appears to happen.
#
That's because `flatMap()` is a transformation and all transformations in Spark are lazy, in that they do not compute their results right away. Instead, they just remember the transformations applied to some base dataset (e.g. a file). The transformations are only computed when an action requires a result to be returned to the driver program. This design enables Spark to run more efficiently – for example, we can realize that a dataset created through map will be used in a reduce and return only the result of the reduce to the driver, rather than the larger mapped dataset.
#
By default, each transformed RDD may be recomputed each time you run an action on it. However, you may also persist an RDD in memory using the persist (or cache) method, in which case Spark will keep the elements around on the cluster for much faster access the next time you query it. There is also support for persisting RDDs on disk, or replicated across multiple nodes.

result.msg:
Note that after you click 'play' in the paragraph above “nothing” appears to happen.

That's because flatMap() is a transformation and all transformations in Spark are lazy, in that they do not compute their results right away. Instead, they just remember the transformations applied to some base dataset (e.g. a file). The transformations are only computed when an action requires a result to be returned to the driver program. This design enables Spark to run more efficiently – for example, we can realize that a dataset created through map will be used in a reduce and return only the result of the reduce to the driver, rather than the larger mapped dataset.

By default, each transformed RDD may be recomputed each time you run an action on it. However, you may also persist an RDD in memory using the persist (or cache) method, in which case Spark will keep the elements around on the cluster for much faster access the next time you query it. There is also support for persisting RDDs on disk, or replicated across multiple nodes.

paragraphs.title: Take a look at first 100 words
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
print words.take(100)   # we're using a take(n) action

# Output: As you can see, each word occupies a distinc array bucket.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Remove Empty Words

Use `filter()` transformation to remove empty words. Remember that in Python the `len()` function returns a length of a string. 
#
Replace `<FILL IN>` with appropriate code.

result.msg:
Remove Empty Words

Use filter() transformation to remove empty words. Remember that in Python the len() function returns a length of a string.

Replace <FILL IN> with appropriate code.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
wordsFiltered = words.filter(<FILL IN>)

paragraphs.title: Solution (click 'Show output')
paragraphs.text:
%md
`wordsFiltered = words.filter(lambda w: len(w) > 0)`

result.msg: wordsFiltered = words.filter(lambda w: len(w) > 0)

paragraphs.title: Get Total Number of Words
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

print wordsFiltered.count()     # using a count() action

%md
#### Word Counts

Let's see what are the most popular words by performing a word count.
Use `map()` and `reduceByKey()` transformations to create tuples of type (word, count). 
#
Replace `<FILL IN>` with appropriate code.

result.msg:
Word Counts

Let's see what are the most popular words by performing a word count.
Use map() and reduceByKey() transformations to create tuples of type (word, count).

Replace <FILL IN> with appropriate code.

paragraphs.title: Word count with a RDD
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

wordCounts = wordsFiltered.map(<FILL IN>).reduceByKey(<FILL IN>)

paragraphs.title: Solution (click 'Show output')
paragraphs.text:
%md
`wordCounts = wordsFiltered.map(lambda word: (word, 1)).reduceByKey(lambda a,b: a+b)`

result.msg: wordCounts = wordsFiltered.map(lambda word: (word, 1)).reduceByKey(lambda a,b: a+b)

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### View Word Count Tuples
Now let's take a look at top 100 words in descending order with a `takeOrdered()` action.

result.msg:
View Word Count Tuples

Now let's take a look at top 100 words in descending order with a takeOrdered() action.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
print wordCounts.takeOrdered(100, lambda (w,c): -c)

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Filter out infrequent words
Use `filter()` transformation to filter out words that occur less than five times.
#
Replace `<FILL IN>` with appropriate code.

result.msg:
Filter out infrequent words

Use filter() transformation to filter out words that occur less than five times.

Replace <FILL IN> with appropriate code.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

filteredWordCounts = wordCounts.filter(<FILL IN>)

paragraphs.title: Solution (click 'Show output')
paragraphs.text:
%md
`filteredWordCounts = wordCounts.filter(lambda (w,c): c > 5)`

result.msg: filteredWordCounts = wordCounts.filter(lambda (w,c): c > 5)

paragraphs.title: Take a Look at Results
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

print filteredWordCounts.collect()   # we're using a collect() action to pull everything back to the Spark driver

result.msg: [(u'all', 7), (u'very', 8), (u'even', 6), (u'repository', 7), (u'FlowFile', 9), (u'use', 7), (u'A', 7), (u'data', 20), (u'a', 60), (u'through', 6), (u'content', 8), (u'This', 8), (u'given', 9), (u'Repository', 6), (u'and', 89), (u'which', 14), (u'The', 28), (u'NiFi', 41), (u'with', 8), (u'Controller', 7), (u'where', 7), (u'Flow', 9), (u'will', 11), (u'is', 62), (u'make', 6), (u'well', 6), (u'the', 110), (u'some', 8), (u'for', 19), (u'dataflow', 12), (u'flow', 11), (u'as', 32), (u'to', 84), (u'be', 26), (u'more', 11), (u'can', 19), (u'how', 7), (u'or', 19), (u'then', 7), (u'each', 6), (u'one', 9), (u'system', 16), (u'their', 6), (u'that', 20), (u'are', 22), (u'between', 6), (u'it', 22), (u'in', 25), (u'on', 17), (u'of', 94), (u'within', 8), (u'an', 6), (u'at', 11), (u'other', 7)]

paragraphs.text:
%md
Now let's use `countByKey()` action for another way of returning a word count.

result.msg: Now let's use countByKey() action for another way of returning a word count.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

result =  words.map(lambda w: (w,1)).countByKey()

# Print type of data structure
print type(result)

result.msg: <type 'collections.defaultdict'>

paragraphs.text:
%md
Note that the **result** is an unordered dictionary of type {word, count}.
Since this is a small set we can apply a simple (non-parallelizeable) python built-in function.

result.msg:
Note that the result is an unordered dictionary of type {word, count}.
Since this is a small set we can apply a simple (non-parallelizeable) python built-in function.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Take a look at first 20 items in our dictionary.

result.msg: Take a look at first 20 items in our dictionary.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
# Print first 20 items
print result.items()[0:20]

result.msg: [(u'', 110), (u'limited', 2), (u'all', 7), (u'concept', 1), (u'managed', 1), (u'contexts,', 1), (u'chain', 1), (u'indicating', 1), (u'partition.', 1), (u'existing', 1), (u'[iot],', 1), (u'executing', 1), (u'Routing,', 1), (u'manages', 2), (u'scale-out', 1), (u'/', 1), (u'invariably', 1), (u'Based', 1), (u'disk', 3), (u'CPU', 2)]

paragraphs.text:
%md
Apply a python `sorted()` function on the **result** dictionary values.

result.msg: Apply a python sorted() function on the result dictionary values.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
import operator

# Sort in descending order
sortedResult = sorted(result.items(), key=operator.itemgetter(1), reverse=True)

# Print top 20 items
print sortedResult[0:20]

%md
## Part 2
#### Introduction to DataFrames and SparkSQL

result.msg:
Part 2

Introduction to DataFrames and SparkSQL

paragraphs.text:
%md
#
In this section we will cover the concept of a DataFrame. You will convert RDDs from a previous section and then use higher level operations to demonstrate a different way of counting words. Then you will register a temporary table and perform a word count by executing a SQL query on that table.
#
By the end of the section you will have learned higher-level Spark abstractions that hide lower-level details, speed up prototyping and execution.

result.msg:
In this section we will cover the concept of a DataFrame. You will convert RDDs from a previous section and then use higher level operations to demonstrate a different way of counting words. Then you will register a temporary table and perform a word count by executing a SQL query on that table.

By the end of the section you will have learned higher-level Spark abstractions that hide lower-level details, speed up prototyping and execution.

paragraphs.title: DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
A DataFrame is a distributed collection of data organized into named columns. It is conceptually equivalent to a table in a relational database or a data frame in R/Python, but with richer optimizations under the hood. DataFrames can be constructed from a wide array of sources such as: structured data files, tables in Hive, external databases, or existing RDDs. [See SparkSQL docs for more info](http://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/sql-programming-guide.html#dataframes).

result.msg: A DataFrame is a distributed collection of data organized into named columns. It is conceptually equivalent to a table in a relational database or a data frame in R/Python, but with richer optimizations under the hood. DataFrames can be constructed from a wide array of sources such as: structured data files, tables in Hive, external databases, or existing RDDs. See SparkSQL docs for more info.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Transform your RDD into a DataFrame and perform DataFrame specific operations.

result.msg: Transform your RDD into a DataFrame and perform DataFrame specific operations.

paragraphs.title: Word Count with a DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# First, let's transform our RDD to a DataFrame.
# We will use a Row to define column names.
wordsCountsDF = (filteredWordCounts.map(lambda (w, c): 
                Row(word=w,
                    count=c))
                .toDF())

# Print schema
wordsCountsDF.printSchema()

# Output: As you can see, the count and word types have been inferred without having to explicitly define long and string types respectively.

result.msg:
root
 |-- count: long (nullable = true)
 |-- word: string (nullable = true)

paragraphs.title: Show top 20 rows
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Show top 20 rows
wordsCountsDF.show()

paragraphs.title: Register a Temp Table
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

wordsCountsDF.registerTempTable("word_counts")

%md
Now we can query the temporary `word_counts` table with a SQL statement.

result.msg: Now we can query the temporary word_counts table with a SQL statement.

paragraphs.text:
%md
To execute a SparkSQL query we prepend a block of SQL code with a `%sql` line.

result.msg: To execute a SparkSQL query we prepend a block of SQL code with a %sql line.

paragraphs.text:
%sql

-- Display word counts in descending order
SELECT word, count FROM word_counts ORDER BY count DESC

paragraphs.text:
%md
Now let's take a step back and perform a word count with SQL

result.msg: Now let's take a step back and perform a word count with SQL

paragraphs.title: Convert RDD to a DataFrame and Register a New Temp Table
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Convert wordsFiltered RDD to a Data Frame
wordsDF = wordsFiltered.map(lambda w: Row(word=w, count=1)).toDF()

paragraphs.title: Use DataFrame Specific Functions to Determine Word Counts
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

(wordsDF.groupBy("word")
        .sum()
        .orderBy("sum(count)", ascending=0)
        .limit(10).show())

paragraphs.title: Register as Temp Table
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Register as Temp Table
wordsDF.registerTempTable("words")

%md

Now perform a word count using a SQL statement against the `words` table and order the results in a descending order by count.
#
Replace `<FILL IN>` with appropriate code

paragraphs.title: Solution (click 'Show output')
paragraphs.text:
%md
`SELECT word, count(*) as count FROM words GROUP BY word ORDER BY count DESC`

result.msg: SELECT word, count(*) as count FROM words GROUP BY word ORDER BY count DESC

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Part 3
#### Spark Streaming

result.msg:
Part 3

Spark Streaming

paragraphs.text:
%md
#
In this section you will learn how to run a word count on a data in motion rather than static data (or data at rest). The code for a Spark Streaming applications closely resembles that of Part 1. The primary difference is that you will work on micro-batches that will be updated with new data on a pre-defined time interval.
#
By the end of this section you will have downloaded a Spark Streaming application, ran it in a *shell in a browser* and interactively tested the Spark Streaming app by manually typing words in a second shell window running Netcat and observing micro-batch processing on that data as it arrives over internal network connection.

result.msg:
In this section you will learn how to run a word count on a data in motion rather than static data (or data at rest). The code for a Spark Streaming applications closely resembles that of Part 1. The primary difference is that you will work on micro-batches that will be updated with new data on a pre-defined time interval.

By the end of this section you will have downloaded a Spark Streaming application, ran it in a shell in a browser and interactively tested the Spark Streaming app by manually typing words in a second shell window running Netcat and observing micro-batch processing on that data as it arrives over internal network connection.

paragraphs.text:
%md

#### Overview

Spark Streaming is an extension of the core Spark API that enables scalable, high-throughput, fault-tolerant stream processing of live data streams. Data can be ingested from many sources like Kafka, Flume, Twitter, ZeroMQ, Kinesis, or TCP sockets, and can be processed using complex algorithms expressed with high-level functions like map, reduce, join and window. Finally, processed data can be pushed out to filesystems, databases, and live dashboards.

![Spark Streaming](http://spark.apache.org/docs/1.6.0/img/streaming-arch.png)

Internally, it works as follows. Spark Streaming receives live input data streams and divides the data into batches, which are then processed by the Spark engine to generate the final stream of results in batches.

![Spark Streaming](http://spark.apache.org/docs/1.6.0/img/streaming-flow.png)

#### DStream

Discretized Stream or DStream is the basic abstraction provided by Spark Streaming. It represents a continuous stream of data, either the input data stream received from source, or the processed data stream generated by transforming the input stream. Internally, a DStream is represented by a continuous series of RDDs, which is Spark’s abstraction of an immutable, distributed dataset (see [Spark Programming Guide](http://spark.apache.org/docs/1.6.0/programming-guide.html#resilient-distributed-datasets-rdds) for more details). Each RDD in a DStream contains data from a certain interval, as shown in the following figure.

![Spark Streaming](http://spark.apache.org/docs/1.6.0/img/streaming-dstream.png)

result.msg:
Overview

Spark Streaming is an extension of the core Spark API that enables scalable, high-throughput, fault-tolerant stream processing of live data streams. Data can be ingested from many sources like Kafka, Flume, Twitter, ZeroMQ, Kinesis, or TCP sockets, and can be processed using complex algorithms expressed with high-level functions like map, reduce, join and window. Finally, processed data can be pushed out to filesystems, databases, and live dashboards.

Internally, it works as follows. Spark Streaming receives live input data streams and divides the data into batches, which are then processed by the Spark engine to generate the final stream of results in batches.

DStream

Discretized Stream or DStream is the basic abstraction provided by Spark Streaming. It represents a continuous stream of data, either the input data stream received from source, or the processed data stream generated by transforming the input stream. Internally, a DStream is represented by a continuous series of RDDs, which is Spark’s abstraction of an immutable, distributed dataset (see Spark Programming Guide for more details). Each RDD in a DStream contains data from a certain interval, as shown in the following figure.

paragraphs.text:
%md
####Now let's proceed to a lab example.

result.msg: Now let's proceed to a lab example.

paragraphs.title: Run the Following to Download a Spark Streaming Demo to Sandbox
paragraphs.text:
%sh

cd /tmp

if [ -e  spark-streaming-demo.py ]
then
    rm -f spark-streaming-demo.py
fi

wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/roberthryniewicz/sample-code/master/spark-streaming-demo.py

%md
#
Here's how the `spark-streaming-demo.py` code you've just downloaded looks like. Make sure you understand what's going on before you proceed. 
#
Several things worth pointing out:
1. We've set a 2 sec batch interval to make it easier to inspect results of each batch processed.
2. We perform a simple word count for each batch and return the results back to the terminal screen with a `pprint()` function.
#

~~~ python
from pyspark import SparkContext
from pyspark.streaming import StreamingContext

# Create a local StreamingContext with two working threads and a batch interval of 2 seconds
sc = SparkContext("local[2]", "NetworkWordCount")
ssc = StreamingContext(sc, 2)

# Create a DStream
lines = ssc.socketTextStream("localhost", 3333)

# Split each line into words
words = lines.flatMap(lambda line: line.split(" "))

# Count each word in each batch
pairs = words.map(lambda word: (word, 1))
wordCounts = pairs.reduceByKey(lambda x, y: x + y)

# Print each batch
wordCounts.pprint()

ssc.start()             # Start the computation
ssc.awaitTermination()  # Wait for the computation to terminate
~~~

result.msg:
Here's how the spark-streaming-demo.py code you've just downloaded looks like. Make sure you understand what's going on before you proceed.

Several things worth pointing out:

  1. We've set a 2 sec batch interval to make it easier to inspect results of each batch processed.
  2. We perform a simple word count for each batch and return the results back to the terminal screen with a pprint() function.

from pyspark import SparkContext
from pyspark.streaming import StreamingContext

# Create a local StreamingContext with two working threads and a batch interval of 2 seconds
sc = SparkContext("local[2]", "NetworkWordCount")
ssc = StreamingContext(sc, 2)

# Create a DStream
lines = ssc.socketTextStream("localhost", 3333)

# Split each line into words
words = lines.flatMap(lambda line: line.split(" "))

# Count each word in each batch
pairs = words.map(lambda word: (word, 1))
wordCounts = pairs.reduceByKey(lambda x, y: x + y)

# Print each batch
wordCounts.pprint()

ssc.start()             # Start the computation
ssc.awaitTermination()  # Wait for the computation to terminate

paragraphs.text:
%md
#
Note that any operation applied on a DStream translates to operations on the underlying RDDs. For example, the earlier example above of converting a stream of lines to words, the flatMap operation is applied on each RDD in the lines DStream to generate the RDDs of the words DStream. This is shown in the following figure.

![Spark Streaming](http://spark.apache.org/docs/1.6.0/img/streaming-dstream-ops.png)

These underlying RDD transformations are computed by the Spark engine. The DStream operations hide most of these details and provide the developer with a higher-level API for convenience.

result.msg:
Note that any operation applied on a DStream translates to operations on the underlying RDDs. For example, the earlier example above of converting a stream of lines to words, the flatMap operation is applied on each RDD in the lines DStream to generate the RDDs of the words DStream. This is shown in the following figure.

These underlying RDD transformations are computed by the Spark engine. The DStream operations hide most of these details and provide the developer with a higher-level API for convenience.

paragraphs.text:
%md

#### Submitting a Spark Streaming Job

This section should be completed within *shell in a browser* since we'll be using a `spark-submit` command to submit our job.

result.msg:
Submitting a Spark Streaming Job

This section should be completed within shell in a browser since we'll be using a spark-submit command to submit our job.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### First, open a "Shell in a Box"

Go to `http://<Host IP>:4200`, for example [http://127.0.0.1:4200](http://127.0.0.1:4200) if you're running a VirtualBox.
#
 User: `root`
 Pass: `hadoop`
#
Next you will be prompted to change your password.
#
Note: Your `Host IP` should be `127.0.0.1` for **VirtualBox** and `172.16.148.128` for **VmWare**, unless you're running your Sandbox in the cloud.
#

result.msg:
First, open a “Shell in a Box”

Go to http://<Host IP>:4200, for example http://127.0.0.1:4200 if you're running a VirtualBox.

User: root
Pass: hadoop

Next you will be prompted to change your password.

Note: Your Host IP should be 127.0.0.1 for VirtualBox and 172.16.148.128 for VmWare, unless you're running your Sandbox in the cloud.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Second, Submit a Spark Streaming Job

Now you're ready to submit a Spark job. In your terminal window copy and paste the following and hit `Enter`:
~~~
/usr/hdp/current/spark-client/bin/spark-submit /tmp/spark-streaming-demo.py
~~~
#
You should see lots of INFO interspersed with Timestamp corresponding to each batch that is updated every 2 seconds:

~~~
===========================================
Time: 2016-03-16 01:26:22
===========================================
~~~

result.msg:
Second, Submit a Spark Streaming Job

Now you're ready to submit a Spark job. In your terminal window copy and paste the following and hit Enter:

/usr/hdp/current/spark-client/bin/spark-submit /tmp/spark-streaming-demo.py

You should see lots of INFO interspersed with Timestamp corresponding to each batch that is updated every 2 seconds:

===========================================
Time: 2016-03-16 01:26:22
===========================================

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Next, Run Netcat

Netcat (often abbreviated to nc) is a computer networking utility for reading from and writing to network connections using TCP or UDP.
#
In your browser, open a second tab or window, and open another "Shell in a Box" by going to `http://<Host IP>:4200`, for example [http://127.0.0.1:4200](http://127.0.0.1:4200) if you're running a VirtualBox.
#
Login to your shell and run the following command to launch Netcat: `nc -l localhost 3333`
#
At this point you should be connected and you may start typing or pasting any text.
#
For example, if you type the following `hello hello world` text in the Netcat window, you should see the following output in the already running Spark Streaming job tab or window:
~~~
===========================================
Time: 2016-03-16 01:26:24
===========================================
(hello, 2)
(world, 1)
~~~

result.msg:
Next, Run Netcat

Netcat (often abbreviated to nc) is a computer networking utility for reading from and writing to network connections using TCP or UDP.

In your browser, open a second tab or window, and open another “Shell in a Box” by going to http://<Host IP>:4200, for example http://127.0.0.1:4200 if you're running a VirtualBox.

Login to your shell and run the following command to launch Netcat: nc -l localhost 3333

At this point you should be connected and you may start typing or pasting any text.

For example, if you type the following hello hello world text in the Netcat window, you should see the following output in the already running Spark Streaming job tab or window:

===========================================
Time: 2016-03-16 01:26:24
===========================================
(hello, 2)
(world, 1)

paragraphs.text:
%md
If you're done playing around, press `Ctrl + C` to stop your process in either tab/window.

result.msg: If you're done playing around, press Ctrl + C to stop your process in either tab/window.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Optional
This section has optional items relating to Spark.

result.msg:
Optional

This section has optional items relating to Spark.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Explore Spark Jobs via Spark UI
If you would like to see the Spark Jobs via the Spark UI go to `http://<Host IP>:4040`, for example [http://127.0.0.1:4040](http://127.0.0.1:4040) on VirtualBox.
#
Click on one the jobs, e.g. your word count or streaming job, and checkout the following sections:
- Timeline view of Spark events
- Execution DAG
- Visualization of Spark Streaming statistics

These will help you better understand what is going on behind the scenes.

result.msg:
Explore Spark Jobs via Spark UI

If you would like to see the Spark Jobs via the Spark UI go to http://<Host IP>:4040, for example http://127.0.0.1:4040 on VirtualBox.

Click on one the jobs, e.g. your word count or streaming job, and checkout the following sections:

  • Timeline view of Spark events
  • Execution DAG
  • Visualization of Spark Streaming statistics

These will help you better understand what is going on behind the scenes.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Getting rid of annoying messages

If you want to remove annoying INFO messages from the Spark streaming terminal window, do the following:

Open `conf/log4j.properties`, for example: `vi /usr/hdp/current/spark-client/conf/log4j.properties`

and Edit log4j.properties:

~~~
# Set everything to be logged to the console
log4j.rootCategory=INFO, console
log4j.appender.console=org.apache.log4j.ConsoleAppender
log4j.appender.console.target=System.err
log4j.appender.console.layout=org.apache.log4j.PatternLayout
log4j.appender.console.layout.ConversionPattern=%d{yy/MM/dd HH:mm:ss} %p %c{1}: %m%n

# Settings to quiet third party logs that are too verbose
log4j.logger.org.eclipse.jetty=WARN
log4j.logger.org.eclipse.jetty.util.component.AbstractLifeCycle=ERROR
log4j.logger.org.apache.spark.repl.SparkIMain$exprTyper=INFO
log4j.logger.org.apache.spark.repl.SparkILoop$SparkILoopInterpreter=INFO
~~~

Replace the first line:
`log4j.rootCategory=INFO, console`
  with
`log4j.rootCategory=WARN, console`
#
Save log4j.properties and restart your spark-submit job. Now you should see only **WARN** messages.

result.msg:
Getting rid of annoying messages

If you want to remove annoying INFO messages from the Spark streaming terminal window, do the following:

Open conf/log4j.properties, for example: vi /usr/hdp/current/spark-client/conf/log4j.properties

and Edit log4j.properties:

# Set everything to be logged to the console
log4j.rootCategory=INFO, console
log4j.appender.console=org.apache.log4j.ConsoleAppender
log4j.appender.console.target=System.err
log4j.appender.console.layout=org.apache.log4j.PatternLayout
log4j.appender.console.layout.ConversionPattern=%d{yy/MM/dd HH:mm:ss} %p %c{1}: %m%n

# Settings to quiet third party logs that are too verbose
log4j.logger.org.eclipse.jetty=WARN
log4j.logger.org.eclipse.jetty.util.component.AbstractLifeCycle=ERROR
log4j.logger.org.apache.spark.repl.SparkIMain$exprTyper=INFO
log4j.logger.org.apache.spark.repl.SparkILoop$SparkILoopInterpreter=INFO

Replace the first line:
log4j.rootCategory=INFO, console
with
log4j.rootCategory=WARN, console

Save log4j.properties and restart your spark-submit job. Now you should see only WARN messages.

This is just the beggining of your journey with Spark. Make sure to checkout these additional useful resources:

4. [pySpark Reference Guide](https://spark.apache.org/docs/1.6.1/api/python/pyspark.sql.html)
